history.content:
for EECS?

Most professors who teach 123 seem to teach it from a theory heavy standpoint.

So if you want to take it to truly understand differential equations better from a proof heavy mathematical perspective, then 123 is a great choice. It covers things like existence and uniqueness of solutions, stability, and some extra topics such as properties of dynamical systems.

But if you're thinking about taking 123 to learn about solving differential equations, or even understanding how problems can be formulated as differential equations, then don't since 123 probably won't spend much time or even cover such topics.

If you want to learn about solving general differential equations, maybe check out Math 228A/B as they're focused on numerically solving them.

There are some EE courses that might help. 120 seems to go over analytically solving difference equations, and the fact that it's about signal processing, and therefore covers transforms like fourier and laplace, means that it will go over tools that can help in analytically solving PDEs and ODEs. I haven't checked out EE128, but ODEs play a huge role in control theory so that might be another good class to learn about such topics.

There are also some physics classes that go over formulating physical systems as differential equations such as physics 105.

Even with all the applications, understanding ODEs might not be too useful. ODEs are thought to be a solved problem, where we already have black boxes that can usually numerically solve our problems better and faster than anything we could code up.

Math 123 covers many important topics. But they may not be important to you. If you're interested in understanding why solutions to ODEs may or may not exist or be unique, or the exact criteria and implications of different types of stability, then Math 123 would be a good course for you.

But if you're just interested in 'solving' them, then the other listed classes will be a lot more relevant.

How useful is Math 123 (ODE) in EECS (in undergraduate, post-grad, and/or workplace)?
history.subject: Math 123 (ODE)
